repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Education Reform Project and
            Reform of Higher Education and Research Project

abstracts.cdata!:
For both projects, outcome is rated
            satisfactory. Institutional development is rated high, and
            sustainability as likely. Bank performance is rated highly
            satisfactory for the Education Reform Project and
            satisfactory for the Higher Education Project. Borrower
            performance for both projects is rated satisfactory.
            Experience with the projects confirms a number of OED
            lessons from education projects: 1) When ministries
            collaborate effectively and borrower staff are committed to
            the reform process, projects that involve multiple
            ministries may be effectively implemented. 2) Comprehensive,
            complex and demanding reforms can work well if initiated
            through respected national institutions, particularly if the
            goals o f the reform are clearly explained to the public. 3)
            Rigid procurement and disbursement requirements imposed on
            smaller institutions (such as schools) or individuals who
            receive grant funds may adversely impact their ability to
            implement their projects. Special efforts may be required to
            limit the paperwork and deadline obligations that grant
            recipients face. 4) Small grants (e.g., for stipends or for
            research) often have a portion contributed by the
            government, since the Bank finances only a percentage.
            Government delays in paying counterpart funds disrupt
            important educational activities o f individuals. Broader
            procurement planning may be needed to ascertain that a
            shortfall or delay will not disrupt crucial activities.

2465763.trustfund:
TF020250-FRENCH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF021393-ROMANIA EDUCATION, TRNG. & EMPLOYMENT,TF022908-PHRD-EMPLOYMENT & SOCIAL PROTECTION,TF021985-HIGHER EDUCATION/SCIENCE &
            TECH. PROJECT,TF031460-ROMANIA - HIGHER EDUCATION PROJECT,TF032196-ROMANIA - HIGHER EDUCATION,TF032197-ROMANIA - HIGHER EDUCATION,TF033385-ROMANIA - HIGHER EDUCATION,TF033390-ROMANIA - HIGHER EDUCATION,TF037840-ROMANIA - HIGHER EDUCATION

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact high. A number of lessons drawn from the
            project are conveyed as follows. The painful circumstances
            prevailing in the country for fundamental social sector
            reforms, were conducive to a difficult, costly, and slow
            process. However, the option chosen in light of the frequent
            political changes (which could have hampered reforms),
            provided the opportunity, to the different leaders, to
            advance the part of the reform closest to their political
            platform. This was possible due to realistic assumptions,
            and implementation arrangements, in line with the situation
            in the country. Moreover, while stakeholder involvement, or
            participatory processes were not an option at preparation,
            the perceived power distance between the Government, and
            individual citizens changed in time, so that by project
            restructuring, participation was included in the pilot
            component on rural education successfully. It is fair to
            point out that despite frequent leadership changes, the
            sustained political commitment was strong, enhanced by a
            broad project design, suitable for each educational vision,
            and strategy. However, the project missed the opportunity of
            using convincingly, the power of good monitoring and
            evaluation, though at final implementation, monitoring
            criteria was used. While disputed arguments over taxation of
            technical assistance (TA) contracts affected sub-components,
            the focused work of TA in educational assessment, achieved
            in a very limited time, was largely successful. Finally, the
            sustained public information campaigns, though only
            implemented at the Mid-Term Review, prominently supported
            changes, directly reaching interested audiences, teachers
            and parents.

18218530.trustfund: TF021393-ROMANIA EDUCATION, TRNG. & EMPLOYMENT,TF022908-PHRD-EMPLOYMENT & SOCIAL PROTECTION,TF020250-FRENCH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education Reform Project will be
            implemented over five years by the Ministry of Education
            (MOE) in close cooperation with its affiliated Institute for
            Education Sciences (IES) and the education inspectroates in
            the country's 41 judets. The project will finance
            textbooks and supplementary materials, equipment, computer
            hardware and software, technical assistance, external and
            local training, preparation of studies, and non-salary
            operating costs. The project will comprise two main
            components: (i) raising the quality of basic and secondary
            education; and (ii) improving education financing and management.
